snippet: Farmers and other poultry experts say coloring chicks is harmless, but animal rights activists say it turns live birds into holiday playthings that are quickly discarded.
abstract: Dyed Easter chicks have been a seasonal staple in parts of the country for generations, though the practice has gone largely underground as society’s tastes have changed; farmers and other poultry experts say coloring chicks is harmless, but animal rights activists say it turns live birds into holiday playthings that are quickly discarded; about half the states and a scattering of municipalities have laws against the practice.
lead_paragraph: Farmers and other poultry experts say coloring chicks is harmless, but animal rights activists say it turns live birds into holiday playthings that are quickly discarded.

headline.main: Nobody Minds Dyeing the Egg, but the Chicken Is Another Story
headline.print_headline: Nobody Minds Dyeing the Egg, but the Chicken Is Another Story
